subsection_content:
Gastroesophageal reflux, like other health abnormalities, if it occurs over a long period of time without proper treatment, will cause many complications, even life-threatening. According to Dr. Trung, prolonged gastric reflux can become the cause of dangerous digestive diseases such as esophagitis, esophageal ulcers, esophageal stenosis, Barrett's esophagus and, more frighteningly, carcinoma. esophageal gland.(3)
Esophagitis is a common complication seen in 50% of patients with gastric reflux. Diagnosed through gastroesophageal endoscopy, patients may have symptoms similar to gastric reflux such as: heartburn, regurgitation, choking, difficulty swallowing, increased salivation, chest pain, etc.; Esophagitis is a common complication seen in 50% of patients with gastric reflux. Diagnosed through gastroesophageal endoscopy, patients may have symptoms similar to gastric reflux such as heartburn, regurgitation, choking, difficulty swallowing, increased salivation, chest pain, etc.
Esophageal stenosis has some symptoms such as chest pain, difficulty swallowing, choking in the neck... Reflux is one of the main causes of esophageal stenosis. During reflux, acid from the stomach flows up into the esophagus, eroding the mucosal layer, leading to esophagitis. Prolonged and high-frequency reflux will cause irreversible damage to the esophagus, forming scar tissue that causes narrowing inside the esophagus. If not treated properly, esophageal stenosis will lead to many dangerous complications, specifically Barrett's esophagus; Esophageal stenosis has some symptoms such as chest pain, difficulty swallowing, choking in the neck... Reflux is one of the main causes of esophageal stenosis. During reflux, acid from the stomach flows up into the esophagus, eroding the mucosal layer, leading to esophagitis. Prolonged and high-frequency reflux will cause irreversible damage to the esophagus, forming scar tissue that causes narrowing inside the esophagus. If not treated properly, esophageal stenosis will lead to many dangerous complications later, specifically Barrett's esophagus.
Barrett's esophagus only occurs in 8-15% of patients with persistent gastroesophageal reflux, but is an extremely dangerous complication and has no special signs other than common reflux symptoms. . If a patient is suspected of having Barrett's esophagus, the doctor will prescribe endoscopy and cell biopsy for an accurate diagnosis. People with Barrett's esophagus need to be treated and closely monitored because this is a complication that has a risk of developing into esophageal adenocarcinoma - although the risk is quite low, prevention and early treatment are important. is still necessary.; Barrett's esophagus only occurs in 8-15% of patients with persistent gastroesophageal reflux, but is an extremely dangerous complication and has no special signs other than common reflux symptoms. . People with Barrett's esophagus need to be treated and closely monitored because this is a complication that has a risk of developing into esophageal adenocarcinoma - although the risk is quite low, prevention and early treatment are important. is still necessary.
Esophageal adenocarcinoma is common in patients over 50 years old and has a high mortality rate. In the early stages, the disease has no clear specific symptoms. When it reaches the development stage, there may be pain in the posterior sternum, hoarseness, unusually rapid weight loss, choking, etc. Because of this dangerous complication, gastric reflux patients are recommended to see a doctor. with digestive specialists to control the disease, have early treatment methods and not create opportunities for the disease to progress more complicatedly.; Esophageal adenocarcinoma is common in patients over 50 years old and has a high mortality rate. Is gastric reflux dangerous? The disease is usually not life-threatening, but can lead to many complications.
